comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That's what I call adding value! Wonderful descriptions - and you've corrected the OCR typos to boot! Impressed.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: Paragon Hotel, Circular Quay, at left, still stands

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The 'Illustrated Sydney News' of 22/2/1868 has full details of Prince Alfred's visit, including a contemporary engraving of the Triumphal Arch - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/5408990 [as usual, found when looking at something else]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a reverse view here - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=220374# . The blurb mentions the sailing ship is the 'Maid of Judah' - I wonder if that is the same ship as in this photo? 3 masts and an aft gaff rig.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Found in the depths of State Records NSW - I bet that is James Barnet (architect) on the left - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: Nice find beachcomberaustralia. Being a temporary structure, I presume it was timber framed and clad in some type of sheeting and perhaps plaster. The picture you found seems to show it was painted to replicate marble.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The State Records NSW photo is now on flickr - James Barnet or not?!
